The European Union on Thursday approved a $43 billion aid package for Greece, bringing the total amount allocated to the country by the European Union to $55 billion. The sum is slightly lower than the $57 billion approved last October, but still large enough to prevent Greece from defaulting on its debt payments. The funding will be split equally between the European Parliament and the European Commission. The total amount already allocated to Greece is $68 billion. The sum is divided into two parts—$42 billion for primary relief, which includes food, energy, and sanitation; and $35 billion for secondary relief, which includes unemployment insurance, cash grants for small businesses and freelancers, and a variety of other initiatives.The aid comes on the heels of the European Commission announcing in February that Greece would receive a total of €52 billion in aid this year, which is nearly half of its original request.
